title: Netflix stock spikes after Q3 earnings beat expectations
text:
Netflix (NFLX) beat third-quarter earnings expectations in its final quarterly report before competitors launch a new batch of streaming services next month.

Here were the main metrics from the report, compared to Bloomberg-compiled estimates:

Revenue: $5.24 billion vs . $5.25 billion expected and $4 billion YOY

GAAP earnings: $1.47 vs. $1.05 per share expected and 89 cents YOY

Domestic streaming paid net adds: +517,000 vs. 800,000 expected and 1.5 million YOY

International streaming paid net adds: +6.26 million vs. 6.2 million expected and 7.3 million YOY

Total paid net streaming additions of 6.8 million came in below the company’s earlier expectations for 7.0 million new subscribers during three months ending in September. However, this still represented an all-time third-quarter record for net adds.

Shares of Netflix rallied 10.4% to $316.53 each as of 4:20 p.m. ET following the release.

Netflix also signaled it was taking strides to stem its free cash outflow. In the third quarter, free cash flow totaled -$551 million, versus -$859 million in the comparable year-ago period. The company reiterated its guidance for free cash flow of about -$3.5 billion for the full year, and expects that free cash flow will improve in 2020 versus the current fiscal year.

For the fourth quarter, however, Netflix’s guidance was light on virtually all major measures. The streaming giant expects to add a total of 7.6 million global subscribers in the final three months of the year, versus consensus expectations for 9.23 million additions. Guidance for fourth-quarter earnings per share of 51 cents came in below expectations for 82 cents a share, and fourth-quarter sales guidance of $5.44 billion was short of expectations by $70 million.

Netflix’s stock has been under considerable pressure since its last earnings report, when the company reported a loss of domestic paid subscribers for the first time since 2011. Shares were down 22% since reporting second-quarter results in July through Wednesday’s close, versus a little-changed S&P 500.

The specter of new entrants into the over-the-top streaming space has been an ongoing overhang for Netflix.

“The launch of these new services will be noisy,” Netflix said in its statement announcing third-quarter earnings. “There may be some modest headwind to our near-term growth, and we have tried to factor that into our guidance. In the long-term, though, we expect we’ll continue to grow nicely given the strength of our service and the large market opportunity.”

Last quarter, the company blamed a weaker slate of content, not an increase in competition, for the miss on new subscribers.

Streaming Wars: Head to Head More

Next month, the pool of streaming services available to consumers is set to become more crowded. Disney (DIS) is set to launch its eponymous streaming service, Disney+, on November 12, priced at $7.99 per month. Apple’s (AAPL) streaming platform will launch November 1 at a starting price of $4.99 per month. Netflix’s standard service currently costs $12.99 per month. That’s in addition to other players already in the space, including Amazon (AMZN) Prime Video.

“Many are focused on the ‘streaming wars,’ but we’ve been competing with streamers (Amazon, YouTube, Hulu) as well as linear TV for over a decade,” Netflix said Wednesday. “The upcoming arrival of services like Disney+, Apple TV+, HBO Max, and Peacock is increased competition, but we are all small compared to linear TV.”

That said, many analysts have remained of the opinion that multiple players will be able to succeed in the new streaming-first arena.

“It is indeed a different operating environment for Netflix going forward, one in which the streaming landscape becomes more populated by large, well-funded players, some of whom are more closely controlling their content distribution,” JPMorgan (JPM) analyst Doug Anmuth wrote in a note ahead of third-quarter results. “But at the same time, we believe the global disruption of linear TV is a strong secular trend that remains early stage in many international markets, and Netflix will remain a key beneficiary as more people cut the cord.”
description: Netflix (NFLX) beat third-quarter earnings expectations in its final quarterly report before competitors launch a new batch of streaming services next month.
